title: VegET - Vegetation ET
subTitle: VegET 2.0
summary: Summary: Vegetation ET (VegET) integrates commonly used water balance algorithms with remotely sensed Land Surface Phenology (LSP) parameter to conduct operational vegetation water balance modeling of rainfed systems at the LSP’s spatial scale using readily available global data sets. Evaluation of the VegET model was conducted using Flux Tower data and two-year simulation for the conterminous US. The VegET model is capable of estimating actual evapotranspiration (ETa) of rainfed crops and other vegetation types at the spatial resolution of the LSP on a daily basis, replacing the need to estimate crop- and region-specific crop coefficients.  Version Updates: Since the last published version in 2008 following features where added: - [...]
body:
Summary: Vegetation ET (VegET) integrates commonly used water balance algorithms with remotely sensed Land Surface Phenology (LSP) parameter to conduct operational vegetation water balance modeling of rainfed systems at the LSP’s spatial scale using readily available global data sets. Evaluation of the VegET model was conducted using Flux Tower data and two-year simulation for the conterminous US. The VegET model is capable of estimating actual evapotranspiration (ETa) of rainfed crops and other vegetation types at the spatial resolution of the LSP on a daily basis, replacing the need to estimate crop- and region-specific crop coefficients.

Version Updates: Since the last published version in 2008 following features where added:
- included snow water equivalent and snow pack parameters
- added deep drainage component ( runoff = surface runoff + deep drainage)
- added ATWI: actual topographic wetness index
- added Irrigation requirement component (netET)
- water mask (water ET is presented as 70% of potential ET)

Requirements: Python 3 install, Supported platforms: Windows.

Dependencies: The model is scripted using Python 3. The set up supports the input data being located on a local system or in a AWS bucket.
Modules used are rasterio, numpy, boto3, fiona, yaml.

Installation: Install Python 3; Use pip/anaconda to install dependencies; Run the model.


Assumptions: Daily precipiation, potential ET and Land Surface Phenology data are key input to estimate ET. The Land Surface Phenology data replaces the need for the Crop coefficient by using the seasonal progression of vegetation growth and development.

Input/Output and Variables: 
Input variables:
Daily precipitation in mm (data source: Gridmet, Precipitation is key driver), daily air temperature in Kelvin (data source: Gridmet), MODIS NDVI daily climatology (data source: MODIS), daily potential ET in mm (data source: Gridmet), soil condition grids: water holding capacity, field capacity, available soil water at 100cm (data source: gNATSGO), DEM

Output variables:
Runoff consisting of Surface Runoff and Deep Drainage (in mm); 
crop ET, actual ET and net ET (in mm) 
soil moisture (in mm)
ATWI: actual topographic wetness index

Treshold parameters (adjusted for data sources described here): 
defining low and high temperature values (in °C) to determine what is snow, sleet, rain:
rf_low_thresh_temp: 0 °C, rf_high_thresh_temp: 6 °C, rf_value: 0.167, melt_factor: 0.06
drainage coefficient: 0.65 = 1 - runoff coefficient: 0.35
values to adjust Land Surface Phenology in the ET calculation:
k factor: 1.25, ndvi_factor: 0.2
water adjustment factor: 0.7 
reference ET bias correction (for Gridmet data source): 0.85
grass to alfa correction factor: 1.25

Temporal Information:
The model is run on a daily time step and the output parameters are presented in mm/daily.

Spatial Information: The input data sets are the determining factor for spatial resolution and extent of output data.

Limitations: Only estimates “rainfed” ET.

Conditions: Since it’s a water budget model, a minimum of 3 month spin-up period is recommended. Valid data for January 2020 would needed the model to start on 1th of October, 2019.

Functions: Forcing variables are: Precipitation, Air Temperature, and potential ET.

Benchmarks: In situ soil moisture and Eddy Covariance station data.

Usage: The paper Senay 2008 had so far over 4500 article reviews and over 35 citations. The model itself is not publicly available yet.

References:
Maselli, F., Angeli, L., Battista, P., Fibbi, L., Gardin, L., Magno, R., Rapi, B., and Chiesi, M., 2020, Evaluation of Terra/Aqua MODIS and Sentinel-2 MSI NDVI data for predicting actual evapotranspiration in Mediterranean regions: International Journal of Remote Sensing, v. 41, no. 14, p. 5186-5205, at https://doi.org/10.1080/01431161.2020.1731000.

Maselli, F., Chiesi, M., Angeli, L., Fibbi, L., Rapi, B., Romani, M., Sabatini, F., and Battista, P., 2020, An improved NDVI-based method to predict actual evapotranspiration of irrigated grasses and crops: Agricultural Water Management, v. 233, at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.agwat.2020.106077.
